document_data.name: Juice of the Vine
document_data.mainbody: '''"Juice of the Vine"''' was a drinking song sung in [[northwest Faerûn]] in the late 15{{th}} century [[DR]]. It celebrated drinking [[wine]], carousing, and relaxing rather than complaining.{{Cite video/Honor Among Thieves}}
document_data.Lyrics:
{{quote|Not fortune found, nor fate divine,
Come close to toping the juice of the vine.
With cherry crew, we sip and sway,
Let's tip the tankard and waste the day.
Reeraw! Well ye ken, our toils can wait for a time.
We saw the folly of men who rather than revel repine.
Reeraw! Well ye ken, our toils can wait for a time.
We saw the folly of men who rather than revel repine.|Lyrics of "Juice of the Vine"}}
document_data.History: In the late 1490s [[DR]],{{HAT-time}} the [[bard]] [[Edgin Darvis]] sung "Juice of the Vine" to rouse his fellow prisoners while cutting ice at [[Revel's End]] prison, though the guard [[Tobias]] ordered him to shut up. He thought it was one of Holga's favorites.
